Participants will be presented with sequential information about a candidate to the Supreme Court: Judge K.
After some preliminary information about Judge K, participants will read a sequence of 4 positions towards Science made by Judge K in the media. After each piece of information, participants will answer two questions: their support for Judge K (on a continuous scale), and the strength of their beliefs towards several statements related to science (on a continuous scale).
 The key dependent variable is the strength of the belief towards these scientific statements (e.g., Climate Change is happening), measured on a continuous scale from 0 to 100 (strongly disagree to strongly agree).

q2.value: Carla Anne Roos, Namkje Koudenburg, Tom Postmes, Jan Failenschmid, Dona Beshka, Lea-Sophie Steingruber

q3.value: In contrast to previous literature suggesting that online interaction is ambiguous and that this ambiguity is problematic, recent research shows that online interaction is actually relatively clear and that this lack of ambiguity makes it harder for interaction partners to navigate their differences of opinion without damaging their social relationship (i.e., to socially regulate). It appears that online interaction partners adapt to a relative lack of subtle social cues by expressing themselves more clearly. In the context of (potential) disagreement, this increased clarity of expression co-occurs with increased perceptions of disinhibited behavior. This contradicts the online dishinhibition literature: rather than actually becoming disinhibited due to a lack of social concerns resulting from anonymity, online interaction partners only appear to be disinhibited because they express their views clearly Furthermore, the online clarity relates to reductions in perceived consensus and solidarity among interaction partners. However, these conclusions are based on correlational data and therefore any conclusions involving causality remain conjecture. With this study we attempt to directly manipulate ambiguity in face-to-face conversations to see whether this indeed results in perceptions of disinhibited behavior and in reductions in experienced consensus and solidarity.

q4.value:
Compared to discussing freely, when participants in a face-to-face discussion group are instructed to write down and read out their thoughts on a controversial topic before starting to discuss it further:

H1: Participants will communicate their opinion more clearly in the start of the discussion.
H2: Participants will perceive each other as more disinhibited, more convinced, and extreme in their opinion.
H3: Participants will experience less consensus and less less solidarity.
H4: Clarity of expression will predict increased perceptions of disinhibition, opinion extremity and convincedness, which results in reductions in experienced consensus and solidarity.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants were recruited from the first year psychology student pool and the psychology paid participant pool of the university of Groningen. Participants received partial course credit or a monetary compensation for their participation. Participants were not allowed to sign in for the study together with a friend or when they were not proficient in English.

These students are invited into the lab in trios. After a short introduction of the study procedure and completing an informed consent form, participants will be presented with a list of 10 politically controversial statements (pilot tested to be polarizing the participant population). They will be asked to indicate their degree of (dis)agreement on each of these statements. The experimental leader will then select two statements on which the trio disagrees. Participants will be asked to discuss the first statement either by engaging in normal face-to-face conversation or by first individually writing down their own opinion and reading this aloud in turn before starting a normal face-to-face conversation. The experimental leader will ask participants to stop their discussion after 5 minutes. After this conversation they will be asked to fill out a self-report questionnaire individually. This procedure is repeated with the other controversial statement in the remaining condition (i.e., speaking or writing). We will audio-record all conversations for content coding. After the second questionnaire has been filled out, participants will be fully debriefed and thanked.

q13.value: We aimed to sample 99 participants in 33 groups to achieve our approximated power level.

q14.value: Power calculation based on similar previous studies.

q15.value: At least 99 participants, full stop after 3 weeks of data collection.

question.value: We used a pilot study to select 10 statements that were controversial among the intended participant sample. Participants in the main study first rated their (dis)agreement with these statements to enable the selection of two statements on which the triad disagreed. The manipulation consisted of letting participants write down their thoughts on this discussion topic in private and reading it out loud to each other in turn before stating to discuss the topic freely. In the control condition, participants only thought about the topic in private before starting to discuss freely.

question.value:
Exploratory content analyses to measure, among others, clarity of expression, degree of responsiveness, and expressed disagreement.

Questionnaire (all five-point scales from disagree to agree) to measure:
-Pre- and post-discussion private attitude measure on the discussion topic.
-Perceived consensus: During this conversation I felt that the other participants and I...: ...understood each other / ...were on the same wavelength / ...agreed with each other / ...had a different opinion (R)
-Solidarity: During this conversation...: ...I identified with the other participants / ...I felt I belonged / ...I felt accepted by the other participants / ...I felt like an outsider (R) / ...I had a good relationship with the other participants
-Own disinhibition: During this conversation...: ...I was polite / ...I thought carefully about how I expressed myself / ...I considered the consequences of what I was saying
-Other disinhibition: During this conversation...: ...I perceived the other participants as polite / ...the other participants thought carefully about how they expressed themselves / ...the other participants seemed to consider the consequences of what they were saying
-Own opinion convincedness/flexibility: ...I am certain about my opinion (R) /...I can easily be convinced to change my opinion
-Other opinion convincedness/flexibility: ...the other participants were certain about their own opinion (R) / ...the other participants could easily be convinced to change their opinion.
-Own opinion tentativeness/clarity: ...I think I expressed my opinion clearly / ...I was tentative in communicating my opinion (R) / ...I felt I was able to communicate my true opinion.
-Other opinion tentativeness/clarity: ...the other participants expressed their opinion clearly / ...the other participants were tentative in communicating their opinion (R) / ...the other participants communicated their true opinions / ...I am confident that I know the other participants' opinions.
-Other opinion extremity: ...the other participants had an extreme opinion / ...the other participants had a nuanced opinion (R)
-Feeling heard: I felt ignored by the other participants.
-Seeking common ground: The other participants and I tried to understand each other. The other participants and I tried to find consensus.
-Conversational flow: This conversation was...: ...smooth / ...harmonious / ...pleasant / ...difficult (R)

question.value:
To assess private attitude change we will subtract the post-discussion from the pre-discussion attitude ratings.

The other variables will be constructed by calculating the means of the corresponding items (as long as these correlate well enough to form reliable scales).

We will perform multilevel repeated measures analyses with the lmer function of the lme4 package in R. Communication condition as a fixed predictor will be nested in participants nested in groups, both of which will be included as random effects. For each dependent variable, we will compare the model with condition as predictor with the associated null model that only includes the intercepts of participant and group. We will include order of conditions as a covariate.

To explore the interrelations between variables and test the hypothesized model (see H4), we will perform repeated-measures correlations. (We expect to have insufficient power to perform mediation analyses).

q21.value: Chi-square outcome of the comparison of model fits of the model with condition as fixed effect predictor with the null model without, cutoff p-value = .05. This will be followed up with estimating the means and 95% confidence intervals per condition with the emmeans package in R. We will calculate the Cohen's d effect size for the differences between conditions. We will also look at repeated measures correlations between the dependent variables, cutoff p-value = .05.

q24.value: We expect to perform an exploratory content analyses on the start of the recorded conversations. The analyses of the variables/items conversational flow, seeking common ground, feeling heard, perceived communication tentativeness, and pre- to post-discussion attitude change will be of an exploratory character. This also largely holds true for the measures of participants' self-rated opinion tentativeness, convincedness and disinhibition. However, we do not expect to find any effects for condition here.

other.value:
Some exploratory analyses may be conducted, testing if the need threats mediate the relation between conditions and lower expectations of chances in the job market, and feelings of demotivation. We may also test if expectations of chances in the job market mediate the relation between conditions and experienced demotivation.

In the results, we describe p-values equal or below 0.05 to be significant, between 0.05 and 0.10 to be marginally significant, and above 0.10 to be non-significant.

sample.value: Data will be collected from approximately 120 female students at Leiden University. As the data collection will continue for the time scheduled in the lab, we may exceed this number.

analyses.value:
For all hypotheses, we will first perform a one-way ANOVA, testing for differences between the three conditions on each dependent variable. Then, two simple contrasts are conducted. Contrast 1 compares confirmations of sexism with the control condition. Contrast 2 compares confirmations of sexism with denials of sexism.

For H1, the above analyses are performed with exclusion as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating higher feelings of exclusion after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating higher feelings of exclusion after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism OR b) not significant, indicating equal feelings of exclusion after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H2, the same analyses are performed with negative feelings as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating more negative feelings after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating more negative feelings after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equally negative feelings after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H3, the same analyses are performed with need threats as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating needs are more threatened after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating the needs to be more threatened after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal need threats after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H4, the same analyses are performed with expectations of success as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating expectations of chances to achieve a desirable job to be lower after confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating expectations to be lower after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal expectations after confirmations and denials of sexism.

For H5, the same analyses are performed with demotivation as a dependent variable. We expect contrast 1 to be significant, indicating higher experienced demotivation towards achieving a desirable job position after exposure to confirmations of sexism than in the control condition. We expect contrast 2 to a) be significant, indicating higher demotivation after exposure to confirmations than denials of sexism, OR b) not significant, indicating equal demotivation after confirmations and denials of sexism.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from the analyses if:

- They do not indicate they identify as female.
- Their answer to the open question shows that they do not recall the results of the research they just read, which is the manipulation.
- They do not complete the full survey.

dependent.value:
All items are answered on a 7-point scale with 1 = Totally disagree, 7 = Totally agree, unless noted otherwise.

Exclusion: "I am being excluded by society”, and "I am being rejected by society".
Need threats: "I do not really feel like I belong in society", and, reverse-scored "I feel accepted by society" (belonging). Reverse-scored: "I experience personal control over where I end up in society", and "I have the feeling that others decide for me where I end up in society" (control). Reverse-scored: "My position in society makes me feel good about myself". and, "My position in society has a negative effect on my self-esteem" (self-esteem). "I feel invisible in society" and, reverse-scored, "My position in society gives me the feelings that my life is meaningful". All items are collapsed into one measure of need threats, if reliability allows.

Negative feelings: “Given my position in society I feel..”, “sad”, “angry”, “hurt”, “happy”, “elated”, “cheerful”, last three items reverse coded (adapted from Van Beest & Williams, 2006). All items are collapsed into one measure of 'feelings' if reliability allows.

Expectations of success: Participants are asked to think of the highest achievable job they could land right after their graduation, and then answer two questions: "I think discrimination will not stand in my way of getting this job", and "Compared to an equally experienced male candidate, my chances of getting this job are smaller". Both items are collapsed into one measure of expectation of success, if reliability allows.

Demotivation is measured with two questions: “How do you feel when you think about  applying for such a job after graduation?", answer options 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated, and 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.

conditions.value:
Participants are assigned to one of three conditions: denial of sexism vs. confirmation of sexism vs. a control condition.

In the denial of sexism condition participants read that research has shown that: a) men and women have equal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is no longer a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to other factors than discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated equally, and e) women are almost never treated in a sexist manner.

In the confirmation of sexism condition participants read that research has shown that: a) men and women have unequal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is still a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated unequally, and e) women are often treated in a sexist manner.

Then, participants are asked to write down in one or two sentences what the most important results of the research were. Then they are given 30 seconds to consider what the results of the research mean for them personally.

In the control condition participants are asked to answer some questions first, and are told that they will read the results of a previous research afterwards.

hypothesis.value:
In news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality, which confirms the occurrence of sexism. This contradicts modern sexist beliefs that deny the occurrence of sexism. In the current research we compare how women respond to denials of sexism vs. confirmations of sexism. We test whether being confronted with messages that confirm the prevalence of sexism may make women feel excluded, and frustrate their expectations and motivation to achieve higher positions in society.

H1: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings of exclusion are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H2: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings are more negative than in the control condition, and equally or more negative than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H3: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s needs are more threatened than in the control condition, and equally or more threatened than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H4: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s expectations of their chances to find a desirable job are lower than in the control condition, and similar or lower than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H5: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s experiences of demotivation towards acquiring a desirable job position are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.

Demotivation is measured with two questions: “How do you feel when you think about  applying for such a job after graduation?", answer options 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated, and 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.
registration_responses.conditions:
Participants are assigned to one of three conditions: denial of sexism vs. confirmation of sexism vs. a control condition.

In the denial of sexism condition participants read that research has shown that: a) men and women have equal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is no longer a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to other factors than discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated equally, and e) women are almost never treated in a sexist manner.

In the confirmation of sexism condition participants read that research has shown that: a) men and women have unequal chances of achievement, b) discrimination against women is still a problem, c) the fact that few women hold high positions in organizations is due to discrimination, d) in British society men and women are generally treated unequally, and e) women are often treated in a sexist manner.

Then, participants are asked to write down in one or two sentences what the most important results of the research were. Then they are given 30 seconds to consider what the results of the research mean for them personally.

In the control condition participants are asked to answer some questions first, and are told that they will read the results of a previous research afterwards.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality, which confirms the occurrence of sexism. This contradicts modern sexist beliefs that deny the occurrence of sexism. In the current research we compare how women respond to denials of sexism vs. confirmations of sexism. We test whether being confronted with messages that confirm the prevalence of sexism may make women feel excluded, and frustrate their expectations and motivation to achieve higher positions in society.

H1: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings of exclusion are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H2: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s feelings are more negative than in the control condition, and equally or more negative than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H3: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s needs are more threatened than in the control condition, and equally or more threatened than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H4: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s expectations of their chances to find a desirable job are lower than in the control condition, and similar or lower than after exposure to denials of sexism.
H5: We predict that after exposure to confirmations of sexism, women’s experiences of demotivation towards acquiring a desirable job position are higher than in the control condition, and similar or higher than after exposure to denials of sexism.

attributes.title: CAN INTERNATIONAL DECELERATIONS AFFECT POLITICAL BEHAVIOR? Trump’s Deal of the Century and Palestinian Voting in Israel

q1.value: CAN INTERNATIONAL DECELERATIONS AFFECT POLITICAL BEHAVIOR? Trump’s Deal of the Century and Palestinian Voting in Israel

q3.value:
Can international decelerations shape political participation? To identify the effects of international decelerations on political participation, I examine whether Donald Trump’s Deal of the Century, which posed a threat of population transfer over a set of Palestinian-Israeli villages in an area called "The Triangle", increased turnout amongst threatened Palestinian voters. To do so, I leverage three recurring national elections within one year, and
implement a difference-in-difference design, comparing Palestinian turnout in "The Triangle" area with Palestinian turnout in all remaining non-Jewish localities in Israel, before and after Trump’s declaration of the deal of the century.

q4.value:
My main expectation is that the threat imposed by Trump’s “Peace to Prosperity” plan will increase political participation amongst voters in the “Triangle Area”. It formally follows that there should be a statistically significant difference in turnout between localities in the “Triangle Area” and all other non-Jewish localities during the third national elections to the 23rd Israeli parliament, which will take place on March 2, 2019.

I also expect to identify a positive effect on Arab Joint List vote share.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
I adapt a difference-in-difference design, which compares changes over time in turnout between non-Jewish localities within and outside of “the Triangle”. Doing so, I seek to recover the effects of the “Peace to Prosperity” plan on voting behavior of Palestinians exposed to the threat of population transfer. By focusing on three consecutive national elections occurring within one year (2019-2020), I reduce concerns regarding time-varying unobservables which may confound my estimates. That said, my empirical inquiry rests on a qualitatively grounded assumption that other than the threat of population transfer imposed by the Deal of the Century (which I seek to identify), there are no factors that systematically differentiate Palestinian localities within and outside of “the Triangle” at the time between the second and third round of elections during the recent years. Under this assumption, and in light of on an evaluation of parallel trends presented in the pdf version of my Pre-analysis plan, I
estimate a difference-in-difference equation (see pdf Pre-analysis plan), amongst all non-Jewish localities in Israel (n =155, over three recurring elections), and cluster errors at the locality level. My main parameter of interest is the DiD estimator (triangleXpost)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: In my study I will analyze data from three consecutive elections. Specifically, my difference in difference design, seeks to identify the effects of an event occurring between the second wave of elections (which took place in Sept 2019), and the third wave of elections which has yet to occur (and will take place on March 2, 2019). Therefore, at the time of pre-registration, I have access only to "pre-treatment data".

question.value: The data I will use is publicly available voting records (at the Israeli locality level). I will get these records from the Israeli central election committee following the elections. In my analysis, I focus on non-Jewish localities.

q13.value: In my study, I observe 155 non-Jewish localities over a three elections (155x3 = 465)

q14.value: I focus on all relevant units for which I have data. Unfortunately, I cannot implement my analysis at the voting booth level, since voting booth codes vary from one cycle to another, limiting my ability construct panel data at the voting booth level.

question.value:
Outcomes:
1. Turnout -- Valid votes/eligible voters.
2. Support for Arab Joint List -- Arab Joint List votes/Valid votes.

Covariates:
1. Post - Binary variable taking the value of 1 for the third election.
2. Triangle - Binary variable taking the value of 1 for the ten Triangle localities.
3. Population - # of locality residents.

*All variables measured at the locality level.

I plan to use a simple OLS (see pdf Pre-analysis plan) :

y = B1xpost + B2xtriangle + B3xpopulation + B4x[postxpopulation] +e

I cluster errors at the locality level, and my main quantity of interest is B4.

attributes.title: Examining Judgements of Ambiguous Extradyadic Behaviours Using Policy Capturing Method

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Examining Judgements of Ambiguous Extradyadic Behaviours Using Policy Capturing Method

sample.value:
We need 130 participants (65 women and 65 men) in the second part of the study (which is the policy capturing study) to have enough statistical power to test all the between-subject and within-subject hypotheses and research questions. Participants in the second part will be chosen from part one based on their romantic relationship status and their willingness to participate in the second part.
Considering the likely attrition rate from part one to part two and the fact that only people who are in a romantic relationship will be invited to participate in part two, we will recruit 260 people to participate in study part one and increase that number, if required, to meet the sample size for part two.

analyses.value:
Multilevel modeling (MLM) will be used to analyze the data. In the current study, the data will be structured such that judgements of profiles (level one) will be nested within individuals (level 2). In this hierarchically structured data, a proportion of the variance in the criterion (judgements in the current research) is attributable to the nesting structure. The nested structure and two levels of analysis justify using MLM as the analysis method in a policy capturing study (Bonaccio & Dalal, 2010). 
The hypotheses and research questions will be tested for each judgement separately.  For H1 and RQ1 we will investigate the relative importance of the cues in making different judgements. Since H1 and RQ1 are focused on within-subject data, they will be addressed at level one analysis. RQ2 is also focused on the within-subject level of analysis but it will investigate the more complex relationships (interactions and non-linear relationship) between the cues and the outcome variables (i.e. judgements). To test the mediation proposed in H2 (also at the within-subject level), we will use PROCESS model or multilevel SEM analysis. 
Jealousy, sociosexual orientation, attachment, gender, personality, implicit theories of relationships, justice sensitivity, relationship quality, and perspective taking will potentially predict how individuals make judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour. The relationship between individual difference variables and judgements will be addressed by H3, H4, H5, H6, H7, H8, H9, H10, H11, RQ4, and RQ5, at a between-subject level (and, therefore, individual difference variables are predictors at level two). 
Finally, cross-level interactions will be investigated to answer RQ3. We will investigate if level two predictors (attachment, jealousy, sociosexual orientation, and gender) interact with level one predictors (secrecy, frequency, and the romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other) to predict participants’ judgements (e.g. attachment × jealousy × sociosexual orientation × gender × secrecy).

outliers.value:
The current study has two parts. In the first part of the study, participants will answer demographics and individual differences measures. In addition, the first part will be used as a screener for the second part of the study in a way that only people who report they are currently involved in a romantic relationship and are interested in participating in our future studies will be invited to participate in the second part of the study. 
Since the inclusion criteria for the second part is to be currently involved in a romantic relationship, we will ask the relationship status question again at the end of the second part. Participants who report they are not involved in a romantic relationship will be excluded from further analyses. 
Additionally, we ask a self-report response quality question at the end of both surveys. We will exclude the data from any participant who reports lack of attention. Finally, at the end of each survey, we ask participants for their permission to retain the data. We will delete their data if they choose not to let us use their data.

After excluding data based on above criteria, we will run our analysis both with and without outliers. We will report whether the results differ in any publications and presentations. Outliers will be identified by computing the overall standard deviation and removing any outliers beyond 3.0 SD above/below the mean.

dependent.value:
The key dependent variables are participant’s judgements regarding whether an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour constitutes an act of infidelity, whether the actor has the intention to cheat, the degree to which such behaviours would cause emotional distress in the participant (we will ask them to take the romantic partner’s perspective), and the likelihood that they would seek to terminate the relationship if the other person in the relationship engaged in such behaviours.
Each dependent variable will be assessed using a single item generated by the researchers. The response scale for all the items ranges from 1 (completely disagree) to 7 (completely agree). The actual items are presented below. In addition, the survey is posted on OSF website. 

My partner is cheating on me by sending direct messages to Natalie.
1                       2                      3                      4                      5                      6                      7
completely disagree                                                                                          completely agree
My partner intends to cheat on me with Natalie.
1                       2                      3                      4                      5                      6                      7
completely disagree                                                                                          completely agree 
I would find my partner sending direct messages to Natalie emotionally distressing.
1                       2                      3                      4                      5                      6                      7
completely disagree                                                                                          completely agree 
I would break up with my partner for sending direct messages to Natalie.
1                       2                      3                      4                      5                      6                      7
completely disagree                                                                                          completely agree

conditions.value:
To describe the conditions, it is needed to mention the method that we are using in our study. We will use a policy capturing method in which each individual is asked to read a series of similar profiles (30 profiles in this study) with varying levels of cues, which act as independent variables. After reading each profile, participants are asked to make judgments related to the goal of the study. During analysis, participants’ responses to the questions are regressed on the cues to determine the relative importance (as indicated by the size of the regression coefficients) of the cues (Karren, & Barringer, 2002). A high number of profiles per person is necessary to have stable estimates of regression coefficients (Aiman-Smith, Scullen, & Barr, 2002). With enough judgments from each individual, the researcher can calculate the weights each person assigned to the cues.  
In our research, the ambiguous or subtle extradyadic behaviour (i.e. sending direct messages on social media) will be held constant across all the profiles. However, the levels of the three contextual factors (i.e. cues) surrounding that ambiguous behaviour will vary across profiles. These cues include frequency of the behavior, secrecy, and the partner’s familiarity with the outside other.
The current study will use a policy capturing method with a fully crossed design. 
In policy-capturing, a fully crossed design means all levels of each of the cues (i.e. contextual factors in this study) are crossed with the levels of the other cues (Aiman-Smith et al., 2002). Therefore, all the participants will judge every possible combination of the different cues’ levels (i.e. 2 [secrecy] × 4 [frequency] × 3 [romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other]), which will result in 24 unique profiles. In addition, each participant will judge duplicates of 6 randomly selected profiles (30 profiles or conditions in total) to enable us to measure test-retest reliability and consistency in their judgements. 

Two example profiles for heterosexual women are presented below:
Your romantic partner has a friend named Natalie he knows from university. Your partner and Natalie have been classmates in some courses. You know Natalie not at all well. Your partner sends direct messages to Natalie on social media a couple of times a day. Your partner does not try to hide from you that he sends messages to Natalie.

Your romantic partner has a friend named Natalie he knows from university. Your partner and Natalie have been classmates in some courses. You know Natalie not at all well. Your partner sends direct messages to Natalie on social media a couple of times a day. Your partner tries to hide from you that he sends messages to Natalie.

hypothesis.value:
In this research, we will investigate the relative influence of several contextual factors on how people perceive ambiguous extradyadic behaviours (operationalized as direct messaging on social media in this study). The contextual factors of interest include frequency of the behavior, whether the perpetrator is hiding the behaviour from their partner, and the partner’s familiarity with the outside other. 
We will examine the relative importance of these contextual factors in the extent to which participants perceive that a) an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour happening in their relationship reflects infidelity, b) their romantic partner has the intention to cheat, c) the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the participant would break up with their romantic partner following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

We will also examine individual differences as predictors of how participants perceive the subtle extradyadic behaviour under investigation. 

Hypothesis 1) Participants will weigh secrecy more heavily than the other contextual factors when making judgements about a) the extent to which an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour reflects infidelity, b) the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, c) the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the extent to which the participant would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour

Research question 1) Do participants weigh frequency of the behaviour and the romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other differently in making each of the following judgements: a) the extent to which an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour reflects infidelity, b) the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, c) the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the extent to which the participant would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour. (For example, do participants weigh frequency more heavily than familiarity when they are judging whether a behaviour is considered infidelity or not?)

Research question 2) Do participants use cues in an interactive or non-linear way to make judgements?

Hypothesis 2) The relationship between the contextual factors (secrecy, frequency, and the romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other) and the participant’s judgement of the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour is perceived as infidelity is mediated by the perception of the actor’s intention to cheat.

Hypothesis 3) Higher levels of jealousy will be associated with higher scores on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 4) Higher scores on sociosexuality (highly unrestricted) will be associated with lower scores on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 5) Higher levels of attachment anxiety will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 6) Higher levels of attachment avoidance will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 7) Women will score higher than men on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 3) Do individual differences in attachment, sociosexual orientation, jealousy proneness, and gender predict how people weigh cues to make different judgements (e.g. people who score high on attachment anxiety weigh cues differently to make judgements in comparison to participants who are low on attachment anxiety)?

Hypothesis 8) Higher levels of relationship quality will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 4) We will explore the influence of justice sensitivity on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 9) Higher scores on growth belief will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 10) Higher scores on destiny belief will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 5) We will explore the influence of perspective taking on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.


Hypothesis 11) Higher levels of honesty humility will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Your partner sends direct messages to Natalie on social media a couple of times a day. Your partner tries to hide from you that he sends messages to Natalie.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In this research, we will investigate the relative influence of several contextual factors on how people perceive ambiguous extradyadic behaviours (operationalized as direct messaging on social media in this study). The contextual factors of interest include frequency of the behavior, whether the perpetrator is hiding the behaviour from their partner, and the partner’s familiarity with the outside other. 
We will examine the relative importance of these contextual factors in the extent to which participants perceive that a) an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour happening in their relationship reflects infidelity, b) their romantic partner has the intention to cheat, c) the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the participant would break up with their romantic partner following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

We will also examine individual differences as predictors of how participants perceive the subtle extradyadic behaviour under investigation. 

Hypothesis 1) Participants will weigh secrecy more heavily than the other contextual factors when making judgements about a) the extent to which an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour reflects infidelity, b) the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, c) the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the extent to which the participant would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour

Research question 1) Do participants weigh frequency of the behaviour and the romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other differently in making each of the following judgements: a) the extent to which an ambiguous extradyadic behaviour reflects infidelity, b) the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, c) the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant, and d) the extent to which the participant would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour. (For example, do participants weigh frequency more heavily than familiarity when they are judging whether a behaviour is considered infidelity or not?)

Research question 2) Do participants use cues in an interactive or non-linear way to make judgements?

Hypothesis 2) The relationship between the contextual factors (secrecy, frequency, and the romantic partner’s familiarity with the outside other) and the participant’s judgement of the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour is perceived as infidelity is mediated by the perception of the actor’s intention to cheat.

Hypothesis 3) Higher levels of jealousy will be associated with higher scores on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 4) Higher scores on sociosexuality (highly unrestricted) will be associated with lower scores on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 5) Higher levels of attachment anxiety will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 6) Higher levels of attachment avoidance will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 7) Women will score higher than men on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 3) Do individual differences in attachment, sociosexual orientation, jealousy proneness, and gender predict how people weigh cues to make different judgements (e.g. people who score high on attachment anxiety weigh cues differently to make judgements in comparison to participants who are low on attachment anxiety)?

Hypothesis 8) Higher levels of relationship quality will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 4) We will explore the influence of justice sensitivity on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 9) Higher scores on growth belief will be associated with lower scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Hypothesis 10) Higher scores on destiny belief will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

Research question 5) We will explore the influence of perspective taking on the judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.


Hypothesis 11) Higher levels of honesty humility will be associated with higher scores on judgements concerning whether the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour is an infidelity, the extent to which the actor has the intention to cheat, the extent to which the ambiguous extradyadic behaviour causes emotional distress in the participant and whether they would break up with the actor following ambiguous extradyadic behaviour.

q2.value: Andrew Kennedy, Paul Dux, Cliff Mallett

q3.value:
The methods used to classify sports coaching expertise vary considerably between studies (see Lyle & Cushion, 2017). Notably, researchers have used variables, such as years of coaching experience; current job title; win/loss record; and the judgements of knowledgeable third-parties to determine sports coaches' level of expertise. These varying methods of classification make it difficult to compare and contrast results across studies exploring sports coaching expertise.
 
In an attempt to devise a more replicable/objective method for measuring sports coaching expertise, the current study will explore the potential of a 22-item self-report measure (working title: expertise in sports coaching scale) to distinguish between sports coaches of varying levels of expertise (e.g., beginner to master). The 22 items were developed in consideration of the body of research on sports coaching expertise and effectiveness (e.g., Gilbert & Côté, 2013; Lyle & Cushion, 2017). The measure has also received content validity feedback and assessments from experienced sports coaching researchers and coach developers. First, a 30 items measure was workshopped with a group of 12 sports coaching researchers and practitioners, to assess the content and scope of the items. Following the workshop, the measure was revised to 25-items. Next the measure received a second-round of content validity assessment from four experienced sport coaching researchers, who provided feedback on the readability, applicability, and discriminability of the items. Subsequently, the 22-item measure was developed and pilot-tested on a population of 10 sports coaches of various levels of self-reported sports coaching expertise.
 
Having a measure such as this will provide sports coaching researchers with a uniform method for determining sports coaches' level of expertise. Thus, providing increased opportunity to compare, contrast, and replicate findings across studies exploring sports coaching expertise.

q4.value: The ultimate aim of the exploratory study is to produce a reliable self-report measure of sports coaching expertise that can be used to replicate or compare results on studies investigating sports coaching expertise.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will use a factor analytical design, to explore the shared variance between individual variables and the factor structure of the 22-item measure of sports coaching expertise, to distinguish between coaches who self-report as beginner, developing, emerging, expert, or master level sports coaches. All participants will complete an online measure of sports coaching expertise.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Access to participants (sports coaches) will be assisted by gatekeepers (e.g., coach developers) from various sporting organisations (e.g., Basketball, Netball, Rugby League, Australian Rules Football, and Rowing). Gatekeepers will help facilitate the distribution of the online survey link (and study information sheet) to potential participants. Concomitantly, participants will be asked to voluntarily complete the expertise in sports coaching measure, online. Additionally, the study intends to collect a spread of data from across all five levels of self-reported sports coaching expertise (i.e., beginner, developing, emerging, expert, and master).

q13.value: A total sample size of greater than 300 participants will be sort.

q14.value: In line with research recommendations (e.g., Comrey, A., & Lee, 1992), 300 participants represent a good sample size for factor analysis. However, larger sample sizes will diminish the error in the data (Yong & Pearce, 2013), as such the total sample size will aim to exceed 300 participants.

question.value:
1. Sports coaching attributes: 22-items, 7-point Likert-scale. Item-1 and item-2 measures “coaching experience”, scale range (item -1: junior participation or senior social level – senior professional or national representative level; and item-2: less than 1-year – 15-years or more). Item-3 and item-4 measure "average weekly time spent working in and on coaching", scale range (item-3 [total hours]: <6-hours - >36hrs; item-4 [hours outside of training and competition coaching]: <1-hour - >20-hours) Items 5 – 22 measure a variety of “coaching attributes”, scale range (extremely low – extremely high, proficiency).   
2. Self-reported sports coaching expertise level: 1-item measure, 5-levels (beginner, developing, emerging, expert, and master). 
3. Demographic data (e.g., age, sex, and sport).

The analysis of data in the current study will use exploratory factor analysis (or structural equation modelling) to test the shared variance and factor structure of the 22-item expertise in sports coaching measure.

q21.value: The analysis of data will use p ≤ 0.05 and/or Bayes factor of 3 for or against the null.

q22.value: Any data involving incomplete survey responses will be disregarded. Outliers will be included in the dataset unless it is obvious that the participant has not attempted to answer the items honestly.

q23.value: Any participants with missing survey response data will be excluded.

q24.value: The analysis of data in the current study will use exploratory analysis (e.g., factor analysis or structural equation modelling) to test the shared variance and factor structure of the 22-item expertise in sports coaching measure.

attributes.title: Ginseng for the treatment and prevention of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
attributes.description: Ginseng is a traditional herbal medicine often used as a complementary therapy to boost the immune system against infections. The main ginseng species used in clinical practice are Korean ginseng (Panax ginseng), American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius), and Chinese ginseng (Panax notoginseng). The aim of the review is to assess whether ginseng can be a useful integrative supplementation for the treatment or prevention of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections (SAURIs).

summary.value:
GENERAL INFORMATION: This is the registration of a review protocol aimed at outlining all essential details regarding our study objectives and design. 
BACKGROUND: Ginseng is a traditional herbal medicine often used as a complementary therapy to boost the immune system against infections. The main ginseng species used in clinical practice are Korean ginseng (Panax ginseng), American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius), and Chinese ginseng (Panax notoginseng). 
OBJECTIVE: The aim of the review is to assess whether ginseng can be a useful integrative supplementation for the treatment or prevention of seasonal acute upper respiratory infections (SAURIs). 
STUDY DESIGN: The study is designed as a systematic review and meta-analysis of the scientific literature.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENT: The research project is not funded and no conflict of interest has to be declared by the authors.

q1.value: The Effect of Language on Bilingual (Spanish/English) Individuals' Political Attitudes and Identity

q3.value:
Previous literature has found that the language (Spanish/English) in which Latinos' take a survey affects the responses they give on a variety of social, political, and self-identification questions. However, most of the these studies draw these conclusion on observational survey data, with only one study randomizing language among bilingual Latinos.

This drives the research question: How does language affect bilingual individuals' social and political attitudes and identity?

This study aims to expand the literature on the effects of language on political opinions by conducting an experiment where the language of a survey (the independent variable) (English/Spanish) is randomly assigned to a sample of bilingual (Spanish/English) individuals. The dependent variable of interests are batteries of social, political, and self-identification questions embedded within the survey. 

The goal of the study is to understand if language has any effect on bilingual individual's policy and social attitudes and if so, how strong is this effect? 

A secondary goal is to understand how other predictors of political attitudes, such as partisanship, interact with language in the formation of individual policy preferences.

q4.value:
H1: Individuals who are assigned to be surveyed in Spanish will be more likely to indicate higher levels of Latino Group Conscious relative to those who are assigned to be surveyed in English.

H2: Individuals who are assigned to be surveyed in Spanish, will be more likely to be supportive of pro-Latino policies (pro-immigration, bilingual education, decreased involvement of local law enforcement in immigration enforcement, etc.) relative to those who are assigned to be surveyed in English.

H2a: Individual partisanship will be a stronger predictor of policy and social attitudes among individuals who are assigned to be surveyed in English relative to individuals that are assigned to be surveyed in Spanish.

H2b: Among those individuals assigned to be surveyed in English, Democrats will be more supportive of pro-Latino policies relative to Republicans.

H3: Republican individuals who are assigned to the Spanish survey will be more supportive of pro-Latino policies relative to Republican individuals who are assigned to be surveyed in English.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study is a between subjects design with two treatments. The treatments are "Spanish" survey and "English" survey.

Treatment is administered through simple randomization (no blocking or clustering).

In order to qualify for the experiment, individuals must show basic fluency in the languages of interests, Spanish and English.

English fluency is assumed as this experiment will be carried out among individuals of Latino descent who live in the United States. Spanish fluency is determined at the beginning of the survey using a single question. Respondent's are asked to read a short story (in Spanish) and answer a single question about the story (also in Spanish). Answering the question correctly will allow the respondent to participate in the study.

After being allowed into the study, the respondent is randomized into either the Spanish or English version of the survey (treatment). Both of the surveys ask the EXACT same questions in the exact same order. The only difference between the surveys is the language in which the language is written (treatment).

q9.value: This study will use simple randomization, randomizing the assignment of individual respondents into either the Spanish or English treatment surveys as they enter the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The data collection process will be done on two separate platforms, Amazon's Mechanical Turk service and my home institution's SONA platform. The survey itself is programmed in Qualtrics.

Regarding the former, the survey will be posted as a HIT on MTurk's job listing. The population of interests is all MTurk workers who are Spanish/English bilinguals and are of Latino descent. The description of the survey will be posted in Spanish. This will act as the first screener for bilingual participants. Should respondents wish to participate in the study they will be provided a link to the first part of the survey. The first part of the survey will ask for the participant’s consent. Due to legal reasons, the consent form is only provided in English to all participants. Participants will then be given the bilingual screener question (a pdf of the question will be uploaded). Participation in the language screener will earn the respondent $0.10. Participants who successfully answer the screener will be given a link to the second part of the survey where treatment will be administered. 

Clicking the link to the second part of the survey will immediately randomize participants into either the English or Spanish survey treatment. Respondents will then take the main survey in that language until completion. Upon completion of the survey, respondents will be awarded with $0.90 for a total of $1 upon successful completion of the survey.

For the latter platform (SONA), the survey will be posted on UC Merced's SONA experiment page where undergraduate students can participate in experiments in exchange for SONA credits (which participating classes take for extra credit). Theoretically, every class at UC Merced that takes SONA credits in exchange for extra credit allows their students to enroll in SONA. UC Merced has a population that is of majority Latino descent and strongly bilingual. The description of the survey will be placed on the SONA studies list. Students will be able to select into the study by clicking the link to the survey. Upon clicking the survey link, respondents will be asked for consent and then be presented with the language screener. Upon successful completion of the language screener, respondents will be randomized into the treatment groups of the survey. Upon successful completion of the survey, respondents will be awarded with 0.5 SONA credits, the equivalent of half hour (minimum) of work.
The time frame for the study will be through March 2020.

q13.value:
The size of the sample will vary between the platforms. On the SONA platform as many 1,000 students may be enrolled in a given semester. However, it is unknown how many of these students are of Latino descent and bilingual (English/Spanish) speakers. SONA provides pre-survey measurements on a few variables of interests including race and multi-lingualism. Current estimates suggest there are about 200 participants who are of Latino descent and bilingual. However as the survey is optional for students who enroll in SONA, the true number of potential participants may be higher.

Several linguistic studies have attempted to understand the demographic profile of bilingual MTurkers. Surveys of English/Spanish MTurkers have achieved N's of about 150-200 respondents.

Between the two samples I expect an N = 300. Of course this is an estimate.

q14.value:
While I do not know how many potential participants exists across the platforms I do have a theoretical cap on sample size.

For the MTurk platform, I currently have a grant of $500 to pay participants. Theoretically, if every participant successfully completes the survey I will be able to recruit 416 participants. This number factors in the 20% fee Amazon charges for each participant. This number does not include participants who do not complete the survey and are only awarded $0.10 cents.

For the SONA platforms, researchers are assigned a fixed number of SONA credits with which to pay respondents for their participation. I have been allotted 120 credits for the Spring 2020 semester. At 0.5 credits a survey, I can theoretically recruit up to 240 respondents.

In total, theoretically, I have a cap of 656 total participants.

This would again be the upper limit and I do not expect to reach this number given the difficult of finding qualified respondents on the MTURK platform.

question.value:
Only one variable will be manipulated in this study. The language of the survey the respondents will take. 

Respondents will either receive a survey that is entirely in English or Spanish. 

To ensure equivalency across the survey items, questions have been drawn from a variety of already existing surveys including the Latino National Political Survey (1989-90) , the Latino National Survey (2006), the Latino Immigrant National Survey (2012), and the Collaborative Multi-Racial Post-Election Survey (2008, 2012, and 2016). 

All of these surveys provide their questionnaires in both English and Spanish and were created with targeting language minorities in mind. 

Where appropriate this researchers own language skills were used to modify the question in order to make them appropriate for a web-based delivery (most of these survey mentioned were administered over the phone).

Since the language of the survey is the only treatment variable, the outcomes variables of interests are all of the variables that the respondent will answer in the survey. 

These include basic demographic questions (age, gender, education, nativity, citizenship, etc). A series of questions that measure the respondents language use. Measures of partisanship and ideology are also included. Respondents are also asked a series of identity questions designed to measure the components of Latino Group Conscious. These questions measure individuals' perceived commonality with one's own ethnic group (Latinos), perceived discrimination, a sense of "linked fate", and a need to politically mobilize to address these group concerns.

The main outcomes variables of interest are located in the Social and Political Attitudes batteries. These questions ask respondents to state their opinion on a variety of social and political issues ranging from abortion, immigration, law enforcement, marijuana, education, etc.  These questions are typical of polls done throughout presidential elections and are measured with Likert style scales (Strongly Agree - Strongly Disagree). 

A copy of the survey is provided.

The primary statistical model that will be used to test the stated hypotheses will be ANOVA. 

Specifically, t-tests will be computed by splitting the sample by treatment group (Spanish/English) and comparing the means of the two groups on the outcome variables of interests measured in the Latino Group Conscious and the Social and Policy Attitudes batteries. (H1 and H2). This is the primary relationship of interests in this study.

For H3a, the sample will be subset by treatment group and then an OLS model will be used test the effect of individual level partisanship on the outcomes measured in the Social and Political Attitudes battery for each treatment group. H3a states that partisanship will be more predictive of social and political attitudes when individuals are surveyed in English as compared to Spanish. Thus I would expect the coefficient for "partyID" to be significant in the English treatment group but not the Spanish group.

This model will also be used to test H3b by checking to see whether the coefficient is in the expected direction for each outcome measure. That is, for the outcome variable that measures how  supportive individuals are of increasing immigration (higher values indicating more support), I would expect the coefficient for PartyID (were higher values indicate strong Republican) to be negative. Strong partisan Republicans are less supportive of increasing immigration. Strong Democrats are expected to be more supportive by comparison. Analysis will be carried out similar for all policy questions.

To test H4, the sample will be subset to Republican identifying individuals from both treatment groups. As hypothesis 4 indicates, I expect Republicans who are assigned to take the survey in Spanish will be more supportive of pro-Latino issues as compared to Republicans who take the survey in English. An OLS regression model will be used to estimate the effect of treatment (language) on individuals' responses to the Latino salient policy questions in the Social and Political Attitudes batteries.
